Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit where the current \\( I(t) \\) is driven by a voltage source \\( V(t) \\). The relationship is governed by a linear differential equation involving a convolution with the impulse response \\( h(t) \\) of the circuit. We analyze how the response changes if we modify the signal using a Laplace transform \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{V(t)\\} = \\tilde{V}(s) \\), apply a filter defined by a function \\( F(s) \\), and then take the inverse transform \\( \\mathcal{L}^{-1}\\{ F(s)\\tilde{V}(s) \\} \\).

If at some time \\( t_1 \\), a secondary filter \\( G(s) \\) is applied as an intervention to the transformed voltage, will the resulting current \\( I(T) \\) at time T > t_1 be affected only by \( G(s) \\) and not by the original filter \\( F(s) \\)?
Explanation: The new filter \\( G(s) \\) introduces an additional alteration to the frequency components of the voltage. The result of \\( I(T) \\) will depend on both the original filter \\( F(s) \\) and the new filter \\( G(s) \\), as the modifications due to these filters cumulatively affect the time-domain characteristics of the input signal.
